IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: MOBILIZE PEOPLE AND RESOURCES TO ADDRESS VITAL ISSUES AND BUILD A STRONGER, THRIVING COMMUNITY.
IRS990.MissionDescription: THE MISSION OF THE FOOTHILLS UNITED WAY, INC. IS TO MOBILIZE PEOPLE AND RESOURCES TO ADDRESS VITAL ISSUES AND BUILD A STRONGER, THRIVING COMMUNITY.
IRS990.Description: Foothills United Way: Foothills United Way (FHUW) is dedicated to engaging our community in order to change conditions and improve lives. More than just meeting needs today, it's about creating long-term sustainable positive change. The collective power of the financial, volunteer, and in-kind contributions of our donors and community partners allows for measurable change in FHUW's Impact Areas: Providing for Community Basic Needs, Promoting Health and Healing, Supporting Children and Youth and Strengthening Seniors.

Activity2.Description: PIE/IDA Program: The PIE/IDA program addresses the root causes of poverty through systemic economic changes benefitting the working poor. Program participants open Individual Development Accounts (IDA's), which are matched savings accounts, designed to help working low-income and low-wealth families save money for continuing education, capitalizing a business or buying a home. The PIE/IDA mission is to provide tools that empower low-income residents to save and build assets to strengthen their economic stability. The program provides a maximum match of $3,000 towards the asset purchase of each program participant. Participants in the program must be in the IDA/PIE Program for at least 6 months and may stay up to 30 months. In 2010, the program graduated 100 participants as follows: 43 home buyers, 37 post-secondary education, and 20 small business start-ups. At June 30, 2010, the program had 82 participants as follows: 36 home buyers, 27 small business start-ups, and 19 post-secondary education.

Activity3.Description: Imagination Library: Imagination Library was created by the Dollywood Foundation in 1996 to provide books for preschoolers in Sevier County, Tennessee. Through enrollment in the Library, children ages 0-5 receive a book mailed to their home each month. The Foundation works in partnership with local organizations to replicate the program in other communities across the country. In April 2003, a group of interested citizens and organizations came together to bring the program to Boulder and Broomfield Counties. Foothills United Way serves as the fiscal agent for the program and maintains the local database. Through June 2010, nearly 1,800 children have received more than 38,900 books FHUW's Imagination Library.

Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Identifier: Procedure for Monitoring Grants in the U.S.:
Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Explanation: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2: The Organization received and reviews an annual report from every funded agency that addresses program results, accomplishments, challenges, and budget variances. Also, volunteer members of the Community Impact Committee make site visits, during the funding cycle period, wherever funded programming is taking place.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 2
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Board member, Albert Manzi, is a board member of the I Have A Dream Foundation of Boulder County, a partner agency that receives funding from the Organization. Board member, John Kottke, is married to the Executive Director of Special Transit, a partner agency that receives funding from the Organization. Board member, John Kottke, is Chair of the Capital Campaign of Special Transit, a partner agency that receives funding from the Organization. Board member, Frank Bruno, is a board member of Special Transit, a partner agency that receives funding from the Organization. Board member, Gilbert Saenz, is a board member of Intercambio de Communidades, a partner agency that receives funding from the Organization. Board member, Greg Harms, is the Executive Director of Boulder Shelter for the Homeless, a partner agency that receives funding from the Organization.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The 990 is reviewed by the board of directors and questions and comments are solicated via electronic distribution of the return.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Board and staff complete a conflict of interest policy statement annually. Annual conflict of interest declarations are reviewed by the Audit Committee for compliance with internal standards as well as potential disclosures.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15a
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Executive Committee of the Board provides an annual performance evaluation of the CEO. Salary determination is based on similiar non-profit entities in the area.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The 990 is available for public review on guidestar. All Organization governing documents, policies and financial statements are available for review at the Organization's offices during normal business hours.
The process has not changed from the prior year.

Form990ScheduleRPartII.PrimaryActivities: Improve lives by mobilizing the caring power of communities around the world
